1. Near-term planning needs for problems with multi-decadal time horizons that permit the adoption of flexible approaches
column30: There are a bunch of decision problems that do not seem amenable to flexible approaches, and are rather more tactical than strategic. Some of the decision problems seem potentially amenable to flexible approaches but may require expertise not in our team. Some [anonymized] projects got decent ratings on this criterion but I expect them to be disqualified based on engagement criteria.

3. Sensitivity of coastal hazards to changing landforms
column30: Clarifications: [R1] Ð I selected flood hazard as promising based on the fact that flood risk can be affected by morphological changes (mostly of the bathymetry); i.e., erosion and deposition during floods and storm events, as well as dredging activities. [m2] Ð Given that flood hazard is not available as a [candidate problem], I chose [harden housing] instead. The reasoning is similar to [R1] (although a different river/estuarine system); flood risk can be affected by changes in the patterns of erosion and deposition during floods and storm events, as well as dredging activities. [R3] Ð I chose [flood protection] based on the same reasoning mentioned above. Flood risk can be affected by erosion and deposition during floods and storm events, as well as dredging activities.

column3: 2. Sensitivity to coastal flooding and other climate hazards, including the confluence of multiple hazards
column30: To be honest, I found the amount of information a bit overwhelming. Maybe that's because I missed the two DA meetings. In principle, I felt that many of the decision problems could be solved by individual engineering companies, leaving it unclear what the role of MACH would be. I would see MACH on a larger scale, providing the boundary conditions that may support any of those decision problems. I therefore tried to evaluate the different locations and their decision more holistically.

column3: 2. Sensitivity to coastal flooding and other climate hazards, including the confluence of multiple hazards
2. Sensitivity to coastal flooding and other climate hazards, including the confluence of multiple hazards
column30: Despite really phenomenal summaries this was challenging. Examples of why 1) for my topic ('2') how much should i focus on sensitivity to the hazards vs. sensitivity to uncertainty in the hazards, and how much should 'sensitivity' be based on our sense of the importance of possible impacts (as opposed to the mechanics of the decision itself), and 2) where the communities were lacking in providing a compelling case, how much should we read between the lines and applying our own priors (vs. relying solely on what was on the page)
